results.title: Cost, profit & break-even (NP)
results.brief_description: John Cleese is joined by John Bird who explains to him why his factory which produces coupled cutlery has gone bankrupt. The film is designed to show the influence of the cost of a product on its price and how the volume produced affects that cost. Also considers how productivity is the only way to increase wages without increasing inflation. Intended for line managers, senior executives and personnel not directly concerned with finance. Suitable for upper secondary level. NB: FOR USE ONLY IN A DOMESTIC SITUATION OR FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES ONLY.

results.title: Breakthrough to literacy
results.creator_credit: Robin Bates and London, Midland and Scottish Railway
results.brief_description: Explains the “Breakthrough” method of teaching children to read and write. Useful for parents and teachers and recommended for education discussion groups. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level.

results.title: Changing...perceptions of development and power in the Australian inner city
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Spring Hill, an inner-city area of Brisbane, Queensland, is the city’s oldest residential suburb and is today (1979) under threat. The film looks at two major processes of urban change: the encroachment of commercial development, which results in wide-scale demolition of housing; and the influx of new residents, the affluent middle class, who have a stake in restoring the older housing and retaining the residential character of the neighbourhood. Spring Hill’s traditional residents, those who once worked on the nearby wharves and those drifting in from the bush in search of cheap accommodation, are caught between these two processes. Drawn into the conflict are outsiders: politicians, planners, social workers, even film crews. The film assesses their impact on the community and raises important questions about power, class and social change. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Incident at Hawk's Hill
results.brief_description: A story based on Allan W. Eckert’s novel “Incident at Hawk’s Hill” about a shy, lonely six-year-old who wanders into the Canadian Prairie and spends a summer under the protection of a badger. Edited from the motion picture entitled “The Boy who talked to badgers”, originally shown in 1974 on the teelevision program “The Wonderful World of Disney”.

results.title: World is born
results.brief_description: Sequence from “Fantasia” interpreting Stravinsky’s “Rites of Spring”. Depicts the first two billion years of the earth’s existence and it formation, convulsions, and upheavals and the first living creatures: unicellular forms, the first amphibians, the dinosaurs, the struggle for existence among the prehistoric monsters and the end of their era.

results.title: The Old mill
results.brief_description: An early Disney color animated cartoon about birds and animals living happily in a deserted old windmill. Their peace and comfort are disturbed by a violent storm. Disney animation, featuring first significant use of multiplane camera. (Award: Academy Award Winner, 1937)

results.title: Thru the mirror
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Educational Media Company
results.brief_description: Mickey Mouse falls asleep reading Lewis Carroll’s ‘Alice Through the Looking Glass’ and dreams himself into wonderland. Features Mickey in 1930’s dance routine. Notable for virtuoso Disney animation techniques, anticipating the design and devices used in the later feature version of Alice in Wonderland.

results.title: The Band concert
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Despite interference from a bee, a noisy Donald Duck playing “Turkey in the Straw”, and a full scale whirlwind, Mickey’s band doggedly performs the “William Tell Overture”. This was the first Mickey Mouse cartoon to use technicolor and is considered to be one of the Disney studios best.

results.title: Steamboat Willie
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Steamboat Willie is the first animated film to use synchronised sound, and the first Mickey Mouse cartoon ever released. Mickey appears as a crew member on a riverboat which is captained by big bad Pete. Minnie Mouse is the passenger who joins Mickey as he uses various props as musical instruments. Animation by Ub Iwerks.
